children.text: If any such pair exists, it outputs "BUG", else "OK".

children.label: language_mapping

children.text:
First, let's outline the steps in Fortran. First part (equivalent to first Java program):

- Read the input string (a character string, e.g., 'LRUUD...').

- Track the path coordinates after each move, storing all positions.

- Check all pairs of points separated by at least 3 steps (i and j where j >= i+3) to see if any are too close (distance in x or y is 0 and the other is <=1).

- If any such pair exists, the result is "BUG", else "OK". Second part (equivalent to second Java program):

- Take the result string ("OK" or "BUG") and process each character to produce the output string of 0/1/2.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: Now, let's code this step by step.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text:
Therefore, the Fortran program can be written as follows. Putting all together:

program main

    implicit none

    character(len=100) :: input_str
    integer :: x = 0, y = 0
    integer, dimension(2, 101) :: co
    integer :: k = 1, i, j, dx, dy, total_positions
    logical :: flag = .true.
    character(len=3) :: first_result
    logical :: s
    character(len=3) :: second_result
    integer :: output_pos = 1

    ! First part: process input string and check coordinates
    read(*,'(a)') input_str

    !
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
Initialize coordinates array
    co(1,1) = x
    co(2,1) = y

    do i = 1, len_trim(input_str)
        select case (input_str(i:i))
            case ('L')
                x = x -1
            case ('R')
                x = x +1
            case ('U') y = y +1
            case ('D')
                y = y -1
        end select
        k = k +1
        co(1,k) = x
        co(2,k) = y
    end do

    total_positions = k

    ! Check all pairs i and j with j >= i+3
    flag = .true. do i = 1, total_positions -3 do j = i+3, total_positions
            dx = abs(co(1,i) - co(1,j))
            dy = abs(co(2,i) - co(2,j)) if ( (dx <=1 .and. dy ==0) .or. (dy <=1 .and. dx ==0) ) then
                flag = .false.
                exit
            end if
        end do
        if (.not. flag) exit
    end do

    ! Determine first_result
    if (flag) then
        first_result = "OK"
    else
        first_result = "BUG"
    end if

    ! Second part: process first_result into second_result
    s = .false. second_result = ''
    output_pos = 1

    do i = 1, len_trim(first_result)
        select case (first_result(i:i))
            case ('.')
                if (s) then
                    second_result(output_pos:output_pos) = '1'
                    output_pos = output_pos +1
                    s = .false.
                else
                    second_result(output_pos:output_pos) = '0'
                    output_pos = output_pos +1
                end if
            case default
                if (s) then
                    second_result(output_pos:output_pos) = '2'
                    output_pos = output_pos +1
                    s = .false. else
                    s = .true.
                end if
        end select
    end do

    !
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: The output is written using trim(second_result(1:output_pos-1)), which trims any trailing spaces. Yes, this should work.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: Thus, the final Fortran program is as above.
children.label: empty

children.text:
Output the result
    write(*,'(a)') trim(second_result(1:output_pos-1))

end program main

Therefore, the Fortran program can be written as follows.

Putting all together:

program main

    implicit none

    character(len=100) :: input_str
    integer :: x = 0, y = 0
    integer, dimension(2, 101) :: co
    integer :: k = 1, i, j, dx, dy, total_positions
    logical :: flag = .true.
    character(len=3) :: first_result
    logical :: s
    character(len=3) :: second_result
    integer :: output_pos = 1

    ! First part: process input string and check coordinates
    read(*,'(a)') input_str

    ! Initialize coordinates array
    co(1,1) = x
    co(2,1) = y

    do i = 1, len_trim(input_str)
        select case (input_str(i:i))
            case ('L')
                x = x -1
            case ('R')
                x = x +1
            case ('U')
                y = y +1
            case ('D')
                y = y -1
        end select
        k = k +1
        co(1,k) = x
        co(2,k) = y
    end do

    total_positions = k

    ! Check all pairs i and j with j >= i+3
    flag = .true.
    do i = 1, total_positions -3
        do j = i+3, total_positions
            dx = abs(co(1,i) - co(1,j))
            dy = abs(co(2,i) - co(2,j))
            if ( (dx <=1 .and. dy ==0) .or. (dy <=1 .and. dx ==0) ) then
                flag = .false.
                exit
            end if
        end do
        if (.not. flag) exit
    end do

    ! Determine first_result
    if (flag) then
        first_result = "OK"
    else
        first_result = "BUG"
    end if

    ! Second part: process first_result into second_result
    s = .false.
    second_result = ''
    output_pos = 1

    do i = 1, len_trim(first_result)
        select case (first_result(i:i))
            case ('.')
                if (s) then
                    second_result(output_pos:output_pos) = '1'
                    output_pos = output_pos +1
                    s = .false.
                else
                    second_result(output_pos:output_pos) = '0'
                    output_pos = output_pos +1
                end if
            case default
                if (s) then
                    second_result(output_pos:output_pos) = '2'
                    output_pos = output_pos +1
                    s = .false.
                else
                    s = .true.
                end if
        end select
    end do

    ! Output the result
    write(*,'(a)') trim(second_result(1:output_pos-1))

end program main
